sub_topic: Using the Fourier transform to solve fluid dynamics problems
message_1: A pipe with circular cross-section of radius 5cm and length 10cm conveys a fluid with velocity u(r) = 8r, where r is the radial coordinate. Calculate the volume flow rate of the fluid.
message_2:
To calculate the volume flow rate of the fluid, we need to integrate the velocity profile u(r) over the cross-sectional area of the pipe. The volume flow rate Q can be expressed as:

Q = ∫∫ u(r) dA

where dA is the differential area element.

For a pipe with a circular cross-section, we can use polar coordinates to express dA as:

dA = r dr dθ

The limits of integration for r will be from 0 to the pipe radius (5 cm) and for θ will be from 0 to 2π. Thus, the volume flow rate Q can be calculated as:

Q = ∫(from 0 to 2π) ∫(from 0 to 5) 8r * r dr dθ

First, we integrate with respect to r:

Q = ∫(from 0 to 2π) [ (8/3)r^3 ](from 0 to 5) dθ

Q = ∫(from 0 to 2π) ( (8/3)(5^3) - (8/3)(0^3) ) dθ

Q = ∫(from 0 to 2π) ( (8/3)(125) ) dθ

Now, we integrate with respect to θ:

Q = ( (8/3)(125) ) [ θ ](from 0 to 2π)

Q = ( (8/3)(125) ) (2π - 0)

Q = ( (8/3)(125) ) (2π)

Q = (1000/3)π cm³/s

So, the volume flow rate of the fluid is approximately 1047.2 cm³/s.
